facts.text: Police charge sheet dated November 13, 1949 originated the proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The police charge sheet dated November 13, 1949, which originated the proceedings out of which this appeal has arisen, was to the effect that the

facts.text: Appellant was Head Clerk of the Civil Surgeons office at Almora

anchor.surface_text: was to the effect that the appellant, the Head Clerk of the Civil Surgeons office at Almora, misappropriated a sum of money entrusted to him

facts.text: Appellant misappropriated a sum of money entrusted to him during a portion of the period he was functioning as Head Clerk

anchor.surface_text: was to the effect that the appellant, the Head Clerk of the Civil Surgeons office at Almora, misappropriated a sum of money entrusted to him during a portion of the period he was functioning as Head Clerk.

facts.text: Charge under s. 409 IPC framed: between September 26, 1947, and February 11, 1948, entrusted with Rs. 1,118-10-9, committed criminal breach of trust

anchor.surface_text: framed, namely, that between September 26, 1947, and February 11, 1948, he in his capacity as a public servant, having been entrusted with Rs. 1,118-10-9, committed criminal breach of trust in respect of that amount.

facts.text: Trial court acquitted the accused because offence not brought home due to improper accounts keeping by accused and two successive Civil Surgeons

anchor.surface_text: The trial court found that on account of the improper and unsatisfactory state of affairs in which the accounts were kept in the Civil Surgeons office, for which not only the accused but two successive Civil Surgeons were responsible, no offence has been brought home to the accused and, therefore, he was acquitted.

facts.text: State appealed to High Court of Allahabad, judgment dated June 7, 1954 set aside acquittal, found guilty under s. 409 IPC, sentenced to 3 months rigorous imprisonment

anchor.surface_text: The State preferred an appeal to the High Court of Allahabad which by its judgment dated June 7, 1954, set aside the acquittal, found the accused guilty of an offence under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code, and sentenced him to rigorous imprisonment for a period of three months.

facts.text: Special leave granted by Supreme Court on July 30, 1954 under Art. 136 Constitution

anchor.surface_text: On an application to this court for special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, the same was granted by the order dated July 30, 1954, and it is in pursuance to the special leave so granted that the appeal is before us.

facts.text: Alleged misappropriation detected some time in March 1948 when Messrs May Baker Ltd. sent reminder for unpaid bills

anchor.surface_text: The alleged misappropriation was detected some time in March, 1948, when Messrs May Baker Ltd., sent a reminder to the Civil Surgeon, Almora, to the effect that certain bills of theirs were unpaid and outstanding.

facts.text: Civil Surgeon Dr. Kar enquired, found appellant on leave, intimated for explanation

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the then Civil Surgeon, Dr. Kar, enquired into the matter and found that the appellant, who was Head Clerk when he took charge, was on leave. On sending an intimation to the appellant to submit an explanation,

facts.text: Appellant sent letter Exhibit P.8 on March 5, 1948 containing statements prosecution alleges show guilt

anchor.surface_text: the latter sent a letter Exhibit P. 8 on March 5, 1948, containing certain statements which the prosecution alleges showed that the appellant was guilty of criminal misappropriation.

facts.text: Money alleged misappropriated recovered from appellant and paid in March 1948 to firms whose bills outstanding but shown paid

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, according to the prosecution, the money alleged to have been misappropriated was recovered from the appellant and paid in March, 1948, to the firms whose bills were outstanding but which had been shown as having been paid in the accounts.

facts.text: Matter to police in June 1949 by Deputy Commissioner Almora ordering Deputy Superintendent of Police

anchor.surface_text: The matter was put into the hands of the police for investigation only in June, 1949, when the Deputy Commissioner of Almora ordered the Deputy Superintendent of Police to look into the matter.

facts.text: Charge-sheet filed on November 13, 1949

anchor.surface_text: After investigation, a charge-sheet was filed on November 13, 1949,

facts.text: Case submitted by S.P.O. Almora on July 10, 1950

anchor.surface_text: and the case was finally submitted by the S. P. O. Almora, on July 10, 1950,

facts.text: Case registered in court of S.D.M. Almora on August 7, 1950 under s.409 IPC

anchor.surface_text: A case was registered in the court of the S. D. M. Almora, on August 7, 1950, against the accused under s. 409 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Magistrate dismissed case under s.249 CrPC on November 30, 1950

anchor.surface_text: As the Magistrate was of opinion that it was an indefinite thing, he consigned the file under s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code, to the record room with the direction that it would be taken out when the documents were available.

facts.text: District Government Counsel applied on June 4, 1951 to summon witnesses

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on June 4, 1951, the District Government Counsel applied to the S.D.M. for summoning some witnesses for examination on June 15, 1951,

facts.text: Proceedings transferred to Judicial Officer Almora, examined witnesses starting June 16, 1951: PW1 Shib Lal Tewari on June 16, PW2 Bishun Singh Aug 21, etc.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings were then transferred to the Judicial Officer, Almora, who began the examination of witnesses on June 16, 1951. He examined P.W. 1 Shib Lal Tewari on June 16, 1951, P.W. 2 Bishun Singh on August 21, 1951, P.W. 3 Mohan Singh on the same date, P.W. 4 Shiv Lal Sah and P.W. 5 D. N. Pandey on October 25, 1951, and Hira Lal P.W. 6 on November 10, 1951.

facts.text: Defence of accused: undisbursed amounts kept in safe, disbursed later, no dominion over money

anchor.surface_text: As stated in the judgment of the High Court the defence of the accused was that the undisbursed amounts were kept in the safe in the office and were disbursed on later occasions though the cash books showed that the disbursements were earlier.

facts.text: High Court considered defence unacceptable, temporary misappropriation based on admissions in Ex. P.8

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court considered this defence as unacceptable and in view of the admissions contained in Ex. P. 8, they came to the conclusion that there has been a temporary misappropriation of the amounts.

facts.text: Important witnesses like two Civil Surgeons and auditors examined on commission by interrogatories

anchor.surface_text: the important witnesses such as the two Civil Surgeons during whose period the alleged misappropriation took place, as well as the auditors, were examined on commission by interrogatories,

facts.text: Supreme Court finds trial vitiated due to improper examination of essential witnesses on commission without following CrPC s.503 procedure

anchor.surface_text: Thus the entire proceedings are vitiated and the evidence of the witnesses taken on commission will have to be completely eschewed from the record.

On an application to this court for special leave under Art. 136 of the Constitution, the same was granted by the order dated July 30, 1954, and it is in pursuance to the special leave so granted that the appeal is before us.

anchor.surface_text: Section 503, as it stood before the amendment of 1955, provided that where in the course of an inquiry, trial or other proceeding under the Code, it appears to a High Court, court of Sessions, District Magistrate or Presidency Magistrate, that the examination of a witness is necessary for the ends of justice,

concepts.interpretation: Court holds that procedure under s.503(2) not followed by subordinate Magistrate issuing commission directly without application to District Magistrate; commissions invalid, trial vitiated.
concepts.unlisted_description: When High Court or District Magistrate etc. may issue commission

anchor.surface_text: One of the methods provided for the examination of witnesses on commission is contained in s. 506, of the Criminal Procedure Code, which is as follows The parties to any proceeding under this Code in which a commission is issued may respectively forward any interrogatories in writing which the court or Magistrate directing the commission may think relevant to the issue,

concepts.interpretation: Allows parties to forward interrogatories; used but improperly without proper authority.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: oach the District Magistrate, for we find in the order-sheet the remarks of the Magistrate, mentioned above at an earlier stage. We have ourselves exa

concepts.unlisted_description: Commission to whom to be issued; parties may forward interrogatories

anchor.surface_text: By the Code of Criminal Procedure Amendment Act, XXVI of 1955, in s. 97, for the words District Magistrate or the Presidency Magistrate in sub-s. 1 of s. 503 the words any Magistrate were substituted and sub-s. 2 was omitted but a proviso was added to sub-s. 1

concepts.interpretation: Amendment expanded authority to issue commissions but pre-amendment rules applied here; subordinate Magistrate still needed to apply to District Magistrate.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: for the purpose of the trial to examine the person named in the margin as a witness on behalf of the prosecution and the District Magistrate, Lucknow

anchor.surface_text: The issuing of a commission under the Code of Civil Procedure is governed by ss. 75-78 and O. XXVI, r. 1 of which lays down the cases in which a court may issue a commission to examine a witness.

concepts.interpretation: Contrasted with CrPC; CPC has specific conditions for commission not present in CrPC but caution required in criminal cases.

Cases in which court may issue commission to examine witness
Commission for examination of witness residing outside jurisdiction etc.

anchor.surface_text: It is an established cardinal principle of Criminal jurisprudence obtainable in all systems of law that in criminal proceedings the evidence against the accused should be recorded in his presence and in open court so that the accused may be enabled to challenge such parts of the statement which he wishes to challenge and the presiding officer may have the advantage and opportunity of hearing the witness in person, noting his demeanour and finding out for himself on such observation whether what the witness deposes is true or otherwise.

concepts.interpretation: Departure only in exceptional cases under CrPC provisions; violation here leads to unfair trial.

issues.text: whether in a prosecution like this ... it can be said that the trial is in strict consonance with established rules of practice and not in violation of the same, where the important witnesses testimony has been obtained outside the court, which has to deal with and determine the case.

anchor.surface_text: The question is whether in a prosecution like this where the Head Clerk of a Civil Surgeons office is being arraigned for criminal breach of trust of sums during a particular period, and especially where the misappropriation, if any, could have been found out much earlier if the superior officers had been prompt in checking the registers and doing the duties assigned to them under the rules and regulations governing the office, it can be said that the trial is in stick consonance with established rules of practice and not in violation of the same, where the important witnesses testimony has been obtained outside the court, which has to deal with the and determine the case.

issues.text: whether there was sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court.

anchor.surface_text: On the assumption that the commission was regularly set up by an order of the District Magistrate as contemplated by the above provisions, the question is as to whether there was sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court.

issues.text: whether the trying Magistrate approached the District Magistrate with an application as contemplated in s. 503(2), Criminal Procedure Code.
whether the District Magistrate exercised his independent judgment or judicial discretion as contemplated in s. 503(2) to issue the commission.

arguments.claim: No offence has been brought home to the accused due to improper and unsatisfactory state of accounts keeping in Civil Surgeon's office for which accused and two successive Civil Surgeons were responsible

anchor.surface_text: The trial court found that on account of the improper and unsatisfactory state of affairs in which the accounts were kept in the Civil Surgeons office, for which not only the accused but two successive Civil Surgeons were responsible, no offence has been brought home to the accused and, therefore, he was acquitted.

arguments.claim: Accused guilty of offence under s. 409 IPC; temporary misappropriation based on admissions in Ex. P.8; defence unacceptable

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court considered this defence as unacceptable and in view of the admissions contained in Ex. P. 8, they came to the conclusion that there has been a temporary misappropriation of the amounts.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court avoids expressing opinion on merits

arguments.claim: Undisbursed amounts kept in office safe and disbursed later despite cash book entries showing earlier; no dominion or possession over money; no criminal misappropriation

anchor.surface_text: As stated in the judgment of the High Court the defence of the accused was that the undisbursed amounts were kept in the safe in the office and were disbursed on later occasions though the cash books showed that the disbursements were earlier.

arguments.court_reasoning: Supreme Court finds unnecessary to opine on defence due to procedural vitiation

arguments.claim: Permission be given to examine three witnesses (Dr. D.M. Kar, R.P. Kapoor, etc.) on commission

anchor.surface_text: the District Government counsel put in an application on October 26, 1951, stating that permission may be given to examine three witnesses on commission.

arguments.court_reasoning: Procedure under s.503 CrPC not followed; commissions invalid

arguments.claim: Questions Nos. 5,6,9 to Dr. Kar are leading and cannot be put in examination-in-chief; appearance of Dr. Kar and Kapoor necessary in court for evidence and cross-examination

anchor.surface_text: On November 12, 1951, the accused put in an application objecting to questions Nos. 5, 6 and 9 to be put to Dr. D. M. Kar on the ground that they are leading questions which cannot be put in examination-in-chief and stating further that the appearance of Dr. D. M. Kar and Sri Kapoor for recording their evidence in person before the court is necessary

arguments.court_reasoning: Magistrate modified questions but proceeded with invalid commission; Supreme Court holds procedure vitiated supporting personal appearance need

arguments.claim: s.249 CrPC could not be applied to this warrant case

arguments.claim: Cardinal principle of criminal jurisprudence: evidence against accused must be recorded in presence and open court for challenge, demeanour observation, effective cross-examination

anchor.surface_text: It is an established cardinal principle of Criminal jurisprudence obtainable in all systems of law that in criminal proceedings the evidence against the accused should be recorded in his presence and in open court so that the accused may be enabled to challenge such parts of the statement which he wishes to challenge and the presiding officer may have the advantage and opportunity of hearing the witness in person, noting his demeanour

arguments.claim: No sufficient justification (unreasonable delay/expense/inconvenience) shown for examining key witnesses (Civil Surgeons, auditor) on commission instead of in court

anchor.surface_text: On the assumption that the commission was regularly set up by an order of the District Magistrate as contemplated by the above provisions, the question is as to whether there was sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court. We have not been shown that the attendance of the two Civil Surgeons, as well as the auditor and the other witness, could not have been procured without an amount of delay, expense or inconvenience

arguments.claim: Trying Magistrate did not approach District Magistrate with application under s.503(2) CrPC for commission
District Magistrate did not exercise independent judicial discretion under s.503(2) to issue or reject commission; merely forwarded
Trying Magistrate issued commissions himself without DM authority; DM Almora only forwarded; violation of s.503 and s.506 CrPC
Sections 503 and 506 CrPC to be used sparingly for important witnesses; only in extreme cases of delay/expense/inconvenience; precedents support examining key witnesses in court
Magistrate's discretion to issue commission is judicial and should not be lightly or arbitrarily exercised

anchor.surface_text: The discretion to be used by the Magistrate is a judicial one and should not be lightly or arbitrarily exercised.

arguments.claim: Entire proceedings vitiated due to improper examination of essential witnesses on commission without compliance with s.503 CrPC; evidence eschewed; no fair trial

anchor.surface_text: Thus the entire proceedings are vitiated and the evidence of the witnesses taken on commission will have to be completely eschewed from the record.

holdings.text: The entire proceedings are vitiated and the evidence of the witnesses taken on commission will have to be completely eschewed from the record.

anchor.surface_text: Thus the entire proceedings are vitiated and the evidence of the witnesses taken on commission will have to be completely eschewed from the record.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Improper issuance of commissions by trying Magistrate without application to District Magistrate under s.503(2) CrPC; District Magistrate failed to exercise judicial discretion and merely forwarded; violation of procedural safeguards and cardinal principle of open court evidence.

holdings.text: The accused has not had a fair trial.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Essential witnesses (Civil Surgeons, auditors) examined on commission without justification or proper procedure, denying accused opportunity for effective cross-examination and court observation of demeanour.

holdings.text: There was no sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court.

anchor.surface_text: On the assumption that the commission was regularly set up by an order of the District Magistrate as contemplated by the above provisions, the question is as to whether there was sufficient justification for deviating from the normal practice of examining witnesses in court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No evidence shown of unreasonable delay, expense, or inconvenience in procuring attendance of key witnesses like Civil Surgeons and auditor; procedure must be attempted first.

holdings.text: The trying Magistrate did not approach the District Magistrate with an application as contemplated in s. 503(2), Criminal Procedure Code.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Record review shows Magistrate issued commissions directly or directed issuance without formal application stating reasons to District Magistrate.

holdings.text: The District Magistrate of Almora has not exercised his independent judgment or judicial discretion as contemplated in s. 503(2) to issue the commission.
holdings.reasoning_summary: District Magistrate merely forwarded summonses issued by trying Magistrate without independent decision to issue or reject after considering reasons.

holdings.text: s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code could not be applied to a case like this as it is not applicable to warrant cases.

anchor.surface_text: As the Magistrate was of opinion that it was an indefinite thing, he consigned the file under s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code, to the record room with the direction that it would be taken out when the documents were available. It has not been explained before us how s. 249 of the Criminal Procedure Code could be applied to a case like this, nor is it applicable to cases falling under the Chapter dealing in the warrant cases

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.249 applies to summons cases, not warrant cases under relevant chapter; no explanation provided for its use.

holdings.text: Sections 503 and 506 CrPC should be used sparingly and only in clearest cases for important witnesses.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedents establish sparing use for key prosecution witnesses; commissions for formal or unavoidable cases only; judicial discretion required.

precedents.citation: Queen-Empress v. T. Burke I.L.R. 1884 6 All. 224.

anchor.surface_text: As early as in the case Queen-Empress v. T. Burke I.L.R. 1884 6 All. 224., it has been held that it is number proper to allow the evidence of an important witness for the prosecution to be taken on companymission on the ground that it would be inconvenient for the witness to attend companyrt.

precedents.cited_proposition: it is not proper to allow the evidence of an important witness for the prosecution to be taken on commission on the ground that it would be inconvenient for the witness to attend court

precedents.citation: Mohammad Shafi v. Emperor A.I.R. 1932 Patna 242

anchor.surface_text: That ss. 503 and 506 of the Criminal Procedure Code should be used sparingly and only in the clearest possible cases, has been laid down in Mohammad Shafi v. Emperor A.I.R. 1932 Patna 242 It is number necessary to refer to case law on the point because the matter is one to be decided on the facts in each case.

precedents.cited_proposition: ss. 503 and 506 of the Criminal Procedure Code should be used sparingly and only in the clearest possible cases

anchor.surface_text: Thus the entire proceedings are vitiated and the evidence of the witnesses taken on commission will have to be completely eschewed from the record.

outcome.relief_summary: Trial proceedings vitiated due to improper issuance of commission for examination of key witnesses without following CrPC s. 503 procedure; evidence taken on commission cannot be used against the accused; no fair trial afforded to the accused.
